results.title: The Medic
results.creator_credit: Maurice Benson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Maurice Benson was posted in Vietnam as a medic, he had no idea how much he was following in his father’s footsteps.

results.title: Bribie
results.creator_credit: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Kevin Brady sets the record straight on the Battle of Bribie, considered to be the closest Australia got to losing a battle in Vietnam. His “digger’s account” illustrates the major obstacles and the bravery shown by the men, who were met with gunfire on landing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kevin Brady, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Kevin Brady sets the record straight on the Battle of Bribie, considered to be the closest Australia got to losing a battle in Vietnam. His “digger’s account” illustrates the major obstacles and the bravery shown by the men, who were met with gunfire on landing.

results.title: Growing up fast
results.creator_credit: John Croxford, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It was itchy feet that encouraged John Croxford to join the Australian Navy. He spent most of his time patrolling the Korean coast where there was no room for mistakes.

results.title: Wake up call
results.creator_credit: Jack Pearce, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Jack Pearce may have missed the war, there was still plenty of dangerous work for him to do, clearing mines up the Queensland coast for the Australian Navy.

results.title: Becoming an Australian
results.creator_credit: George Logan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It wasn’t until George Logan served in the army overseas that he felt like a true Australian. Serving as an infantryman in Malaya and Vietnam, it was the values of mateship, care and concern for others that remain with Logan today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Logan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: It wasn’t until George Logan served in the army overseas that he felt like a true Australian. Serving as an infantryman in Malaya and Vietnam, it was the values of mateship, care and concern for others that remain with Logan today.

results.title: Always a survivor
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Catterall and ACMI
results.brief_description: When David Catterall returned from the horrors of the Vietnam War, he found his personal and professional life disintergrating. It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, David Catterall and ACMI
results.description: When David Catterall returned from the horrors of the Vietnam War, he found his personal and professional life disintergrating. It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.

It was then that Catterall discovered the supportive community made up by his fellow returned soldiers and credits them with enabling him to pull through some of the darkest moments of his life.

results.title: Packages from home
results.creator_credit: Dave Piggott, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Dave Piggott went to fight in the Vietnam War at 19, it was a very different world to life back in Australia. With the help of the friends he made in the army, he soon got used to life there and it’s the funny stories and good friends that remain with him today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dave Piggott, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Reminiscing
results.creator_credit: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Alf Thornton fondly recalls his time serving in the Australian Navy during World War II, when letting your mates down was more feared than being killed. When Thornton returned, he spent most of his time trying to regain his lost youth but eventually found an anchor on the H.M.A.S. Castlemaine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alf Thornton, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Interview with Christopher Doyle
results.brief_description:
Australian cinematographer Christopher Doyle talks about how time operates in his filmmaking, how life experience has shaped his work, the role of repetition, structure and movement in cinematogrpahy, how space informs and influences his technique, and about the collaborative process of filmmaking.
Includes clips from ‘Paranoid Park’ 2007; ‘Days of Being Wild’ (A Fei zheng chuan), 1990; ‘Happy Together’ (Chun gwong cha sit), 1997; ‘In the Mood for Love’ (Fa yeung nin wa), 2000; and ‘Fallen Angels’ (Duo luo tian shi), 1995.
results.description:

Includes clips from ‘Paranoid Park’ 2007; ‘Days of Being Wild’ (A Fei zheng chuan), 1990; ‘Happy Together’ (Chun gwong cha sit), 1997; ‘In the Mood for Love’ (Fa yeung nin wa), 2000; and ‘Fallen Angels’ (Duo luo tian shi), 1995.

results.title: In conversation with Graham Leader
results.brief_description:
‘Heartworn Highways’ (1981) captures singer-songwriters such as Townes Van Zandt, Guy Clark, Rodney Crowell, a young Steve Earle and Steve Young living and performing in the heart of pure Country.
Producer Graham Leader talks about the genesis of the documentary ‘Heartworn Highways’. Interview recorded as part of ‘Drifters, Dreamers and Cowboys’ 24 November 2008.
